speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: SCENE XV. The same. A monument.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter CLEOPATRA and her maids aloft, with CHARMIAN and IRAS

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Be comforted, dear madam.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: No, I will not:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: All strange and terrible events are welcome,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: But comforts we despise; our size of sorrow,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Proportion'd to our cause, must be as great

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: As that which makes it.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Enter, below, DIOMEDES

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: How now! is he dead?

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: His death's upon him, but not dead.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Look out o' the other side your monument;

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: His guard have brought him thither.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Enter, below, MARK ANTONY, borne by the Guard

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O sun,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Burn the great sphere thou movest in!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: darkling stand

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The varying shore o' the world. O Antony,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Help, friends below; let's draw him hither.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Peace!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Not Caesar's valour hath o'erthrown Antony,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: But Antony's hath triumph'd on itself.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: So it should be, that none but Antony

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Should conquer Antony; but woe 'tis so!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I am dying, Egypt, dying; only

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I here importune death awhile, until

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Of many thousand kisses the poor last

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I lay up thy lips.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I dare not, dear,--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Dear my lord, pardon,--I dare not,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Lest I be taken: not the imperious show

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Be brooch'd with me; if knife, drugs,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: serpents, have

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Edge, sting, or operation, I am safe:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And still conclusion, shall acquire no honour

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Demuring upon me. But come, come, Antony,--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Help me, my women,--we must draw thee up:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Assist, good friends.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: O, quick, or I am gone.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Here's sport indeed! How heavy weighs my lord!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Our strength is all gone into heaviness,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That makes the weight: had I great Juno's power,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The strong-wing'd Mercury should fetch thee up,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And set thee by Jove's side. Yet come a little,--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Wishes were ever fools,--O, come, come, come;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: They heave MARK ANTONY aloft to CLEOPATRA

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And welcome, welcome! die where thou hast lived:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Quicken with kissing: had my lips that power,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Thus would I wear them out.

speaker: All
text_entry: A heavy sight!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I am dying, Egypt, dying:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Give me some wine, and let me speak a little.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: No, let me speak; and let me rail so high,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That the false housewife Fortune break her wheel,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Provoked by my offence.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: One word, sweet queen:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Of Caesar seek your honour, with your safety. O!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: They do not go together.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Gentle, hear me:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: None about Caesar trust but Proculeius.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: My resolution and my hands I'll trust;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: None about Caesar.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The miserable change now at my end

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Lament nor sorrow at; but please your thoughts

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: In feeding them with those my former fortunes

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Wherein I lived, the greatest prince o' the world,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The noblest; and do now not basely die,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Not cowardly put off my helmet to

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My countryman,--a Roman by a Roman

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Valiantly vanquish'd. Now my spirit is going;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I can no more.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Noblest of men, woo't die?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Hast thou no care of me? shall I abide

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: In this dull world, which in thy absence is

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: No better than a sty? O, see, my women,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: MARK ANTONY dies

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The crown o' the earth doth melt. My lord!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O, wither'd is the garland of the war,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The soldier's pole is fall'n: young boys and girls

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Are level now with men; the odds is gone,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And there is nothing left remarkable

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Beneath the visiting moon.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Faints

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: O, quietness, lady!

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: She is dead too, our sovereign.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Lady!

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Madam!

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: O madam, madam, madam!

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Royal Egypt, Empress!

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Peace, peace, Iras!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: No more, but e'en a woman, and commanded

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: By such poor passion as the maid that milks

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And does the meanest chares. It were for me

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To throw my sceptre at the injurious gods;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To tell them that this world did equal theirs

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Till they had stol'n our jewel. All's but naught;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Patience is scottish, and impatience does

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Become a dog that's mad: then is it sin

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To rush into the secret house of death,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Ere death dare come to us? How do you, women?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What, what! good cheer! Why, how now, Charmian!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: My noble girls! Ah, women, women, look,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Our lamp is spent, it's out! Good sirs, take heart:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: We'll bury him; and then, what's brave,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: what's noble,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Let's do it after the high Roman fashion,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And make death proud to take us. Come, away:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: This case of that huge spirit now is cold:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Ah, women, women! come; we have no friend

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: But resolution, and the briefest end.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Exeunt; those above bearing off MARK ANTONY's body

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: SCENE I. Alexandria. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's camp.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, AGRIPPA, DOLABELLA, MECAENAS, GALLUS, PROCULEIUS, and others, his council of war
